I hired a candidate who didn’t meet the educational requirements. She didn’t have an MBA.

It came down to her and another candidate. I liked her humility. The other candidate was very boastful about the college he went to and his accomplishments. The HR manager was really impressed with him.
As the hiring manager, I had the final decision and I chose her.
She turned out to be an excellent team player.

I have learnt over the years that having a degree does not make you better at performing at a job. It does not override qualities as humility, authenticity and integrity. In today's world, we need to place higher metrics on these qualities because they are becoming extinct.

Don’t pick up that phone yet!
When you first learn of your separation, your first instinct

may be to hit your network, send out resume and race into your job search with a full head of steam.  After all, you didn’t get to this point of your career by just waiting for things to happen.  You don’t want to burn out a good contact before you have taken the time to adjust to the new situation and conscientiously develop your career plan

Start by taking some time to insulate yourself from the outside world. Be kind to yourself and those close to you.  Don’t seek immediate solutions to problems.  Don’t worry about contacting executive recruiters just yet. Save your network until you are in a better emotional state. While it is tempting to dust off your resume and email it right away, take some time to do this right. Above everything else, don’t say negative things about your former employer – either in person, on the phone or online
Now is the time to manage your stress and to begin thinking

There is a difference between having access to coverage and access to care. People might be able to afford coverage, but struggle to pay the additional costs for such things as deductibles and copayments. This affects their ability to afford care. We need to bridge the gap between these issues to ensure all Americans can receive high-quality, affordable health care.

Jeannette was one of a small group of people who launched a research infrastructure in support of clinical studies involving human biospecimens and data collection. Jeannette's skill set extends beyond administrative support into project management. Jeannette has an intuitive and logical mind, she is forward-thinking and a problem-solver focused on efficient and effective solutions. Jeannette is a gentle giant in task management and accountability for timelines and stretching toward goals. Loved working with Jeannette for all of her professional strengths and even more so for all of her genuine care, concern, kindness, optimism, integrity and sense of humor.

summary: A highly accomplished and knowledgeable RN clinical research professional. 20 years of clinical trial experience in varying roles:           Research Operations – research administration, clinical trials management, site recruitment,    resource planning, staffing, training/development, monitoring           Regulatory – billing determinations, contracting, de novo and 510k submissionTherapeutic areas of expertise:           14+ years of bedside nursing experience in telemetry and multi-specialty ICU settings           16+ years of Cardiovascular experience (6 years in research)           4+ years of Oncology experience in research
